sections.title: Maximize Your Social Security Benefit
sections.subtitle: Understand how claiming age, earnings history, and spousal rules shape your retirement income

How work income affects benefits before full retirement age

sections.title: Benefit Basics
sections.content: Social Security replaces a portion of your average indexed monthly earnings from your 35 highest earning years. Filing at full retirement age (FRA) delivers 100% of your primary insurance amount. Claiming earlier permanently reduces benefits, while delaying past FRA boosts them by 8% per year until age 70.

points.title: Full Retirement Age
points.description: For most people retiring today, FRA ranges from 66 to 67 depending on birth year.

points.title: Early Claiming
points.description: Taking benefits at 62 can cut payments by as much as 30%.

points.title: Delayed Credits
points.description: Waiting past FRA adds 0.67% per month (8% annually) until 70.

sections.title: Spousal Strategies
sections.content: A lower-earning spouse can receive up to 50% of the higher earner's FRA benefit. Survivor benefits can reach 100% of the deceased spouse's payment.

sections.title: Earnings Tests and Taxation
sections.content: If you claim before FRA and keep working, the earnings test can temporarily withhold $1 in benefits for every $2 earned above $25,000 (2025 single filer). Withheld benefits are recalculated at FRA, so they are not lost forever. Up to 85% of Social Security can be taxable depending on combined income, so coordinate withdrawals with your tax plan.

sections.title: Plan Your Claim
steps: Create a "my Social Security" account at SSA.gov to view projected benefits.
Note your FRA and calculate benefits at 62, FRA, and 70.
List expected income sources and identify years where delaying Social Security fills a gap.
If married, map out claiming ages for both partners and consider survivor protection.

sections.title: Coordinate with Taxes
sections.content: Use Roth conversions or strategic withdrawals before claiming Social Security to keep taxable income lower later.
